Automated Release Tooling (ART).description: The ART team manages OpenShift build and release processes, builds nightly releases, promotes nightly builds to Engineering/Release Candidates, creates z-stream releases for versions, and addresses build issues. Key responsibilities include evolving build automation, coordinating golang version bumps, migrating from legacy Brew/OSBS to Konflux build system, addressing CVEs, implementing hermetic builds, and providing support through the #forum-ocp-art Slack channel

repos.description: Backing for ART Jenkins jobs and pipelines
Bot for slack-based access to build and release information
Automated Release Team tooling
Configuration data used to build OCP images
Validation of ocp-build-data Image & RPM declarations
React/NextJS Web dashboard for tracking and managing ART build and releases processes
Backend for dashboard to track and manage ART build and releases processes
Automated Release Team documentation

Autoscaling.description: Support and maintain pod and node autoscaling operators for OpenShift

Research and proofs-of-concept
Cluster Autoscaler is a tool that automatically adjusts the size of the Kubernetes cluster
The cluster-autoscaler-operator manages deployments of the OpenShift Cluster Autoscaler using the cluster-api provider
Autoscaling-related components

Karpenter is a Kubernetes Node Autoscaler built for flexibility, performance, and simplicity.

Bare Metal Networking (On-Prem Networkin.description:
Description and Mission:  The On-Prem networking team is responsible for the networking components
required to install, configure and administer OpenShift in on premise environments such as
bare metal, VMWare, OpenShift Virtualization and OpenStack.  This team also owns the Kubernetes
NMState Operator which is used to observe and update the node network state and network configuration.
This team also provides networking services not present in non-cloud environments (API and ingress
load balancing, DNS, VIPs, etc)

Goals:  Our goal is to deliver a consistent networking experience across public cloud and on-premise
environments.

Challenges:  Customer on-premise environments are extremely heterogeneous with many advanced
features (multi-NIC, NIC bonding, complex VLAN configuration, external load balancing, etc).
Determining what configurations are supportable and best-practices for configuring OpenShift on-prem
networking in these environments is a major challenge.

repos.description: Runtime configuration renderer for OpenShift in platforms without Cloud DNSaaS
Declarative node network configuration driven through Kubernetes API.
Declarative node network configuration driven through Kubernetes API.

CID.description: The team is the owner of oc-mirror, an OpenShift CLI plugin responsible to mirror container images needed to install and upgrade Openshift, Operators, Helm Charts and Individual Images on Disconnected environments.

repos.description: Lifecycle manager for internet-disconnected OpenShift environments

Cluster Infrastructure.description:
The OpenShift Cluster Infrastructure team is responsible for the foundational compute infrastructure
and lifecycle management of OpenShift clusters across multiple cloud providers (AWS, Azure, GCP, vSphere, Nutanix, IBMCloud). The team owns and maintains the core APIs and operators
that enable declarative infrastructure provisioning, scaling, and management through both the Machine API
and Cluster API frameworks.

Key areas of responsibility include:
- Cloud Controller Managers (CCM) for all supported cloud platforms
- Machine API operators and cloud-specific providers for node lifecycle management
- Cluster API operators and cloud-specific providers for modern infrastructure management
- Control Plane Machine Set Operator (CPMSO) for HA control plane management
- Machine Health Check for automated node remediation
- Machine CSR Approver for automated certificate signing

This team ensures that OpenShift clusters can be deployed, scaled, and maintained reliably across
diverse infrastructure environments while providing consistent Kubernetes-native APIs for infrastructure management.

repos.description:
AWS Cloud Controller Manager - Implements cloud provider interface for AWS,
managing load balancers, node lifecycle, and cloud-specific resources in Kubernetes.
Part of the shift from in-tree to external cloud providers.

Azure Cloud Controller Manager - Implements cloud provider interface for Azure,
managing Azure-specific resources like load balancers, storage, and node metadata.
Enables seamless integration between Kubernetes and Azure infrastructure.

Azure Service Operator (ASO) - Manages Azure resources (databases, caches, VNets, etc.)
using Kubernetes-native CRDs. Allows declarative Azure resource provisioning directly
from Kubernetes manifests without leaving the cluster API.

GCP Cloud Controller Manager - Implements cloud provider interface for Google Cloud Platform,
managing GCP load balancers, persistent disks, and node topology. Handles cloud-specific
operations for OpenShift clusters running on GCP.

IBM Cloud Controller Manager - Implements cloud provider interface for IBM Cloud,
integrating OpenShift with IBM Cloud infrastructure services including VPC networking
and storage resources.

IBM Cloud VPC Load Balancer Controller - Specialized controller for managing IBM Cloud
VPC load balancers, handling service type LoadBalancer resources in IBM Cloud environments.
Works in conjunction with the IBM Cloud Controller Manager.

vSphere Cloud Controller Manager - Implements cloud provider interface for VMware vSphere,
managing vSphere-specific resources, storage volumes, and virtual machine lifecycle
for OpenShift clusters running on vSphere infrastructure.

Nutanix Cloud Controller Manager - Implements cloud provider interface for Nutanix AHV,
integrating OpenShift with Nutanix infrastructure for storage, networking, and compute resources.
Enables OpenShift to leverage Nutanix platform capabilities.

Cluster API Core - Upstream Kubernetes Cluster API bringing declarative, Kubernetes-style
APIs to cluster creation, configuration, and management. Provides the foundation for
infrastructure-as-code using custom resources like Cluster, Machine, and MachineDeployment.

Cluster CAPI Operator - Manages the installation, configuration, and lifecycle of Cluster API
components on OpenShift clusters. Handles deployment of CAPI controllers and ensures proper
integration with OpenShift platform services.

Cluster API Actuator Package - Shared end-to-end test framework and common utilities
for Cluster API and Machine API providers. Provides standardized testing infrastructure
to ensure consistency and reliability across different cloud provider implementations.

Cluster API Provider AWS (CAPA) - Implements Cluster API infrastructure provider for AWS,
enabling declarative management of AWS resources (EC2, VPC, ELB, etc.) through Kubernetes CRDs.
Supports both cluster provisioning and day-2 machine lifecycle operations.

Cluster API Provider Azure (CAPZ) - Implements Cluster API infrastructure provider for Azure,
managing Azure VMs, networking, and resource groups through Kubernetes-native APIs.
Provides declarative infrastructure management for Azure-based OpenShift clusters.

Cluster API Provider GCP (CAPG) - Implements Cluster API infrastructure provider for Google Cloud,
managing GCP Compute Engine instances, VPCs, and cloud resources using declarative CRDs.
Handles both initial provisioning and ongoing machine lifecycle management.

Cluster API Provider IBM Cloud (CAPIBM) - Implements Cluster API infrastructure provider for IBM Cloud,
enabling declarative management of IBM Cloud VPC infrastructure, virtual servers, and networking
through Kubernetes-native APIs.

Cluster API Provider vSphere (CAPV) - Implements Cluster API infrastructure provider for VMware vSphere,
managing virtual machines, storage, and networking in vSphere environments through Kubernetes CRDs.

Machine API Operator (MAO) - Core operator managing the Machine API framework, including custom resource
definitions (Machine, MachineSet, MachineDeployment), controllers, and RBAC. Orchestrates machine
lifecycle and delegates cloud-specific operations to provider-specific actuators.

Machine API Provider AWS - Implements Machine API actuator for AWS, translating Machine resources
into EC2 instances with proper networking, IAM, and security group configuration. Handles creation,
deletion, and status reporting of worker and control plane machines on AWS.

Machine API Provider Azure - Implements Machine API actuator for Azure, managing Azure VM lifecycle,
availability sets, and managed disks based on Machine resource specifications. Integrates with
Azure APIs for compute resource provisioning and deprovisioning.

Machine API Provider GCP - Implements Machine API actuator for Google Cloud Platform, creating and
managing Compute Engine instances with appropriate machine types, disks, and networking based on
Machine resource definitions. Handles GCP-specific configuration and lifecycle.

Machine API Provider Nutanix - Implements Machine API actuator for Nutanix AHV platform, managing
virtual machine lifecycle on Nutanix infrastructure. Integrates with Nutanix Prism APIs for VM
provisioning, configuration, and cleanup operations.

Machine API Provider IBM Cloud - Implements Machine API actuator for IBM Cloud, managing virtual
server instances in IBM Cloud VPC environments. Handles VPC-specific networking, storage, and
compute provisioning through IBM Cloud APIs.

Cluster Cloud Controller Manager Operator (CCCMO) - Platform operator that manages the deployment,
configuration, and lifecycle of cloud-specific Cloud Controller Managers. Ensures the appropriate
CCM is deployed based on the underlying infrastructure platform and handles upgrades.

Cluster Control Plane Machine Set Operator (CPMSO) - Manages control plane machine lifecycle in
highly available OpenShift clusters. Enables declarative control plane scaling, automated recovery,
and rolling updates of control plane machines across availability zones.

Cluster Machine Approver - Automatically validates and approves Certificate Signing Requests (CSRs)
from nodes attempting to join the cluster. Performs security checks against Machine API and Cluster API
resources to ensure only legitimate nodes receive certificates for cluster access.

Infrastructure Provider Onboarding Guide - Comprehensive documentation and best practices for
integrating new infrastructure providers (cloud or on-premises) into OpenShift. Covers implementing
Machine API actuators, Cluster API providers, and Cloud Controller Managers.
Insights Operator
Deployment Validation Operator

Console.description: Console builds the OCP Console which is a friendly `kubectl` interface in the form of a single page webapp.  It also integrates with other services like monitoring, chargeback, and OLM.  In addition to the OCP Console webapp, the Console team provides a set of backend services to support the webapp and a Dynamic Plugins SDK, a set of libraries to support the creation of UI plugins which can be designed, developed, and released independently of the OCP team release cadence.

Core Networking.description: The OpenShift Core Networking team is dedicated to providing reliable, scalable, and high-performance connectivity for all OpenShift platforms and form factors. We are responsible for the core Kubernetes networking (SDN) layer, including routing, service connectivity, encapsulation, and network policy, as well as advanced networking features. A key part of our mission is ensuring seamless internal cluster communication and smooth integration with external provider networks through advanced mechanisms like BGP. Our work involves both maintaining the foundational components and developing enterprise-grade, real-world network features that satisfy diverse customer infrastructure requirements.

repos.description: Multus CNI is a container network interface (CNI) plugin for Kubernetes that enables attaching multiple network interfaces to pods. Typically, in Kubernetes each pod only has one network interface (apart from a loopback) -- with Multus you can create a multi-homed pod that has multiple interfaces. This is accomplished by Multus acting as a "meta-plugin", a CNI plugin that can call multiple other CNI plugins.

An admission controller to check resources as defined by the Network Plumbing Working Group de-facto CRD specification upon their creation. This admission controller is aware of some of the aspects of what's required when you create NetworkAttachmentDefinition custom resources, and can report back to the user that those resources are well formatted, to improve their experience.

Kubernetes provides Network Policies for network security. Currently net-attach-def does not support Network Policies because net-attach-def is CRD, user defined resources, outside of Kubernetes. multi-network policy implements Network Policiy functionality for net-attach-def, by iptables and provies network security for net-attach-def networks.
An IP Address Management (IPAM) CNI plugin that assigns IP addresses cluster-wide.
network-metrics-daemon is a daemon component that collects and publishes network related metrics

CNI (Container Network Interface) consists of a specification and libraries for writing plugins to configure network interfaces in Linux and Windows containers, along with a number of supported plugins. CNI concerns itself only with network connectivity of containers and removing allocated resources when the container is deleted.
route-override IPAM works as meta CNI plugin to override IP route given by previous CNI plugins.

OVN-Kubernetes (Open Virtual Networking - Kubernetes) is an open-source project that provides a robust networking solution for Kubernetes clusters with OVN (Open Virtual Networking) and Open vSwitch (Open Virtual Switch) at its core. It is a Kubernetes networking conformant plugin written according to the CNI (Container Network Interface) specifications.

The CNCC is a controller/operator which interfaces with the cloud API endpoints to execute and perform the set up required on behalf of the user creating / updating / deleting the CRs this controller manages. The user in the OpenShift use-case are the network plugins (openshift-sdn / OVN-Kubernetes) which interface with this component using its CRDs.
The Cluster Network Operator installs and upgrades the networking components on an OpenShift Kubernetes cluster.

The egress-router plugin creates some sort of cluster-network-external network interface and assigns a user-provided static public IP address to it. It is designed for use by the OpenShift egress-router feature, but may have other uses as well.
Ingress node firewall implements Kubernetes operator to provision stateless ingress node level firewall rules, stateless ingress node firewall implementation is done using eBPF XDP kernel plugin

network-tools is a collection of tools for debugging OpenShift cluster network issues. It contains both debugging scripts (described in the next section) and useful tools to get information from the cluster. This repo is supposed to be used by network engineers and support to debug and diagnose issues. Customers can also be advised to use commands from this image to help get required information.

CoreOS.description: Develop, build, and maintain Red Hat CoreOS for OpenShift

Hive and Cloud Credential Operator team.description: Hive provides centralized, declarative management of multiple OpenShift clusters through a single control plane. CCO encompaces a legacy controller and command line based capability to create cloud credentials currently supporting passthough, mint, and token based authentication. Token based authentication utilizes mutating admission webhooks to automatically configure pod authentication.

repos.description: Hive automates OpenShift cluster creation and deletion via ClusterDeployment CRs using the OpenShift Installer, scales worker nodes through MachinePools/MachineSets with autoscaling and multi-AZ support, and pauses idle clusters for cost savings with fast restart through hibernation. It enables Day 2 operations (CRUD) on resources across managed clusters using SyncSets, accesses clusters on private networks via Private Link, and automates DNS zone delegation and validation through Managed DNS. Additionally, it maintains pre-provisioned clusters ready for immediate claim and use in Cluster Pools, syncs control plane certificates and ingress configs from hub to spokes, and provides HiveUtil as an internal CLI for cluster interaction and debugging.
Standard Operating Procedure Documents for OpenShift Hive
Cloud Credential Operator
Google Pod identity webhook is a Kubernetes mutating admission webhook that automatically configures pods to use IAM roles for service accounts.
The Amazon EKS Pod Identity Webhook is a Kubernetes mutating admission webhook that automatically configures pods to use IAM roles for service accounts
Azure Pod identity webhook is a Kubernetes mutating admission webhook that automatically configures pods to use IAM roles for service accounts

Metal Platform.description:
Automated deployments and hardware management for bare-metal IPI, ZTP, as well as recently introduced
BareMetal-as-a-Service. The team is working with the Metal³ and Ironic upstreams.

The main entry point of the Metal platform is the BareMetalHost CRD provided by BareMetal Operator.
BareMetalHost API is used by OpenShift Installer, Machine and Cluster API and by assisted service
as part of ZTP. It can also be used by customers directly as part of the BMaaS feature.

Ironic is used as a backend for all bare-metal features, but it is not directly exposed to customers.

This team is not responsible for bare-metal UPI or MetalLB.

repos.description: Install an OpenShift 4.x cluster

OpenShift fork of the container image for Ironic provided by Metal³.

This image provides entry points for Ironic and its auxiliary services:
httpd, dnsmasq, ironic-prometheus-exporter and ramdisk logs downloader.

Container image for Ironic Python Agent.

This image provides a way to run Ironic Python Agent inside a CoreOS based ramdisk.
It also features an OpenShift-specific plug-in for Ironic Python Agent that
integrates with CoreOS Installer and Assisted Agent.

Sidecar container to download CoreOS for Ironic.

This container is no longer used for new installations.

OpenShift Machine API provider that integrates with Metal³.

Machines are provided by selecting an available BareMetalHost resource and
instructing BareMetal Operator to provision it.

Cluster API infrastructure provider that integrates with Metal³.

Machines are provided by selecting an available BareMetalHost resource and
instructing BareMetal Operator to provision it.

OpenShift cluster operator that manages bare-metal resources.

This cluster operator is reponsible for installing and managing Metal³ and Ironic
in an OpenShift cluster. The installation is controlled by a Provisioning CR.

Cluster BareMetal Operator is not the same as BareMetal Operator.

OpenShift fork of Metal³ BareMetal Operator.

BareMetal Operator is a controller for BareMetalHost and associated Kubernetes resources.
BareMetalHost is the main API in Metal³ responsible for bare-metal enrollment,
inspection, preparation, provisioning and deprovisioning.
BareMetal Operator uses Ironic as the backend.

OpenShift fork of Metal³ Ironic Standalone Operator.

Ironic Standalone Operator is a controller for Ironic resources.
It is responsible for provisioning and managing Ironic itself.

The plan is for Ironic Standalone Operator to replace parts of
Cluster BareMetal Operator in OpenShift 4.22.
Builds a container image containing the current Machine OS ISO

OpenShift specific controller for Metal³ PreprovisioningImage resources.

This controller is responsible for building CoreOS based ramdisks that launch
Ironic Python Agent on start-up. It also injects networking configuration
into the ramdisk.
OpenShift fork of Sushy: Python client library for Redfish protocol.
OpenShift fork of Ironic: service for managing and provisioning Bare Metal servers.

OpenShift fork of ironic-lib: python library of common ironic utilities.

This library is no longer used by current versions of Ironic and OpenShift.
OpenShift fork of Ironic Python Agent: in-ramdisk agent for Ironic.

OpenShift fork of Ironic Inspector: hardware introspection daemon for OpenStack Ironic

Ironic Inspector is no longer used by recent versions of OpenShift.
Scripts to automate development/test setup for openshift integration with https://github.com/metal3-io/

Terraform provider for Ironic.

The provider is no longer used by recent versions of OpenShift.

Network Ingress and DNS.description: Provide the best solutions for network ingress and DNS in OpenShift, including HAProxy router, Gateway API, CoreDNS, AWS Load Balancer, and External DNS.

Network Observability.description:
Description and Mission: The Network Observability team provides solutions to visualize
and analyze network traffic flows in a Kubernetes or OpenShift cluster.  Network flows
are captured using an eBPF agent and flows are enriched with Kubernetes metadata in a
pipeline which stores the flows in Loki and metrics in Prometheus for advanced query,
filtering and topology visualization.   Advanced functionality is provided in OpenShift
for observability of core networking features such as network policy, UDN and BGP.

Goals: Our goal is to provide rich observability for general networking in a Kubernetes cluster.
Beyond that we want to provide observability as a Day 0 experience for OpenShift networking and
to provide observability for new OpenShift core networking features as they are delivered.

Challenges: The fast-paced feature development in core networking often means that observability
lags by one or more releases.  Our goal is to close this gap and deliver observability alongside
the core features.

repos.description: Network Observability plugin for the Openshift Console
Transform flow logs into metrics
Network Observability eBPF Agent
Network Observability CLI Plugin

An OCI container runtime monitor.

This is the repo that tracks all patches to the OpenShift distribution of Kubernetes on branches corresponding to OpenShift releases.  See https://github.com/openshift/kubernetes/blob/master/README.openshift.md for more
Analyzes resource usage and performance characteristics of running containers.

OpenShift BuildConfig.description: The OpenShift BuildConfig team is part of sustaining engineering team who now owns BuildConfigs module of OpenShift which is feature complete.Earlier this was owned by Openshift Builds team.

repos.description:
We own only openshift-controller-manager build controller code and functionality.
But not other controllers like service account, image reg etc.

OpenShift Builds.description: The OpenShift Builds team owns BuildConfigs, s2i, Shared Resources, Shipwright, the Builds for OpenShift layered product, and Jenkins.

OpenShift Jenkins.description: The OpenShift Jenkins team is part of sustaining engineering team who now owns Jenkins module of OpenShift which is feature complete. Earlier this was owned by Openshift Builds team.

Operator Lifecycle Management.description:
Operator Lifecycle Manager (OLM) extends Kubernetes to provide a declarative way to install, manage,
and upgrade Operators and their dependencies in a cluster. The team maintains the add-on operator
management infrastructure for OpenShift.

OLMv0 includes the original on-cluster operator lifecycle manager, the Marketplace operator for
catalog management, and operator-registry/opm for off-cluster catalog generation and management
tooling. Operators managed by OLMv0 can be installed from multiple catalog sources including
Red Hat certified operators, community operators, and custom catalogs. For more information
about upstream OLMv0, see https://olm.operatorframework.io.

OLMv1 represents the next generation of operator management with components like
cluster-olm-operator (which manages installation and upgrade of OLMv1 within OpenShift), catalogd
and operator-controller that provide improved architecture, performance, and flexibility for
managing operators in Kubernetes environments. For more information about upstream OLMv1, see
https://operator-framework.github.io/operator-controller.

The team plays a key role in defining and driving the overall layered product strategy within
Red Hat. This includes close collaboration with the Konflux team and with all layered product
teams through the Operator Framework Program and mailing list (operatorframework-pgm@redhat.com).

The team are core maintainers of the Operator Framework upstream community and maintains the
standards and tooling for operator packaging, distribution, and lifecycle management. The team
also collaborates frequently with upstream Kubernetes projects including
sigs.k8s.io/controller-runtime, k8s.io/apimachinery, and sigs.k8s.io/crdify.

Over the Air Updates (OTA).description: The Over the Air Updates(OTA) team is responsible for the entire OpenShift cluster update ecosystem, managing how OpenShift clusters discover, validate, and apply updates across all supported versions and channels. The team's primary functions include managing the update service with cincinnati, managing the upgrade graph curation with cincinnati-graph-data, track success/failure rates across the global OpenShift fleet, respond to update-related service disruptions and upgrade blockers.

repos.description: An update protocol system designed for OpenShift cluster lifecycle management. It uses a sophisticated directed acyclic graph (DAG) based approach for managing software updates. The architecture is composed of Graph Builder and Policy Engine, where Graph Builder constructs DAG from release metadata, ensures acyclic properties and Policy Engine applies filtering logic and policies to update graphs.

Cincinnati Graph Data is the configuration repository for OpenShift's update management system. It defines which OpenShift releases are available through different update channels and specifies restrictions on update paths between releases. The core functions include validing upgrade paths between OpenShift releases, managing candidate → fast → stable release promotions, blocking problematic updates through conditional or absolute restrictions, providing additional metadata for older releases.

A core OpenShift component that manages cluster upgrades by reconciling release payload images containing core resources and cluster operators. It implements systematic rollout of cluster operator updates, manages ClusterVersion custom resource with upgrade status and conditions, queries Cincinnati update service for available upgrade paths, validates and applies Kubernetes manifests in dependency order.
An operator that manages OpenShift Update Service (Cincinnati) lifecycle.

Shift on Stack.description: The Shift on Stack team develops the integration between OpenShift and OpenStack.

repos.description: An OpenStack Implementation of Machine API using upstream cluster-api-provider-openstack functions as a backend
A set of Kubernetes controllers to manage your OpenStack infrastructure
OpenStack-specific tests for OpenShift
kuryr-kubernetes - CNI plugin using OpenStack Neutron and Octavia to provide networking for pods and services.

Storage.description:
OCP Storage team is responsible for development and maintenance of the internal
OpenShift and Kuberentes storage APIs, built-in volume plugins, CSI drivers and
all the CSI sidecars shipped in the core OpenShift payloads and some additonal
OLM managed CSI drivers and operators: AWS EFS, Samba, GCP Filestore and Local
Storage Operator.

The team does not maintain or develop any ODF related CSI drivers or operators,
OpenStack CSI drivers or KubeVirt CSI driver and operator.
